displayed_text: Patient: Filled it. Doctor: Oh okay. Patient: But she won’t give me an oral surgeon there. She was scared to do it. Because she was scared I might- Doctor: We’ll hold off on that other shot because it messes up the healing after they do procedures. Patient: But see, but see I havent’ - I haven’t called yet Dr. V____. Doctor: That’s okay. That’s okay. Patient: They said call, okay. Doctor: That’s okay since you just had the filling we need to wait it out… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …before we give you that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay?

Patient: Right. Doctor: So you have to have loose bowels. That means – Patient: That’s what I’m talkin’ about. Doctor: Soft. Stool softeners. Patient: Stool softeners. Doctor: Absolutely. Patient: They ain’t workin’ like they’re supposed to, doc! Doctor: There’s no way that we can get you not pooping correctly because there’s so many different types of laxatives out there – Patient: Yeah, well. Doctor: You just need to take more. Patient: Oh. Okay. Doctor: Yeah. You just don’t have enough – Patient: Enough.

Family Member 1: I’ll call. Doctor: Yeah. All right. Family Member 1: So did W___ then tell you that he's been getting these cramps in his legs? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member 1: Okay, that and then number two, he did say you know, his gums are real sensitive, but he never told me. Patient: Oh no, no, no. That was when I was taking the Elida. Doctor: Yep. Patient: Or when I would I brush my teeth. Doctor: Yep. Yep. So is it better now on the medicine? Patient: It’s gone. Family Member 1: So that might happen with this pill now, right? Or we don't know? Doctor: We don't know, anything is possible, but most of it is, you know, it's going to be very cyclical, right? Patient: Right.

Patient: Well I got a… Doctor: But you don’t want to. Patient: I got to address that. I got to address that and… Doctor: All the more reason to do surgery if it holds up your paddleball and all that stuff right? Patient: Well maybe, yeah, right. Family Member: Well what the – will that lesions – his legs are really weak and they hurt. Would that lesion? Patient: It’s not bad is it? Doctor: I mean I don’t think it’s worse, but it’s not getting better. Family Member: So would that lesion affect his legs also, is it the same stem you know nerve system? Doctor: You know usually not. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Because I mean hopefully – the arm nerves are on the outside. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: She knows V____. Doctor: Right. Patient: Then she left me. Doctor: She left you. Patient: Remember I told you last summer. Doctor: Yeah you did. I remember there was some family issues. Patient: Yeah and she’s gone man. Doctor: She’s gone because of this yeah. Patient: Yeah and so I said I meet, you know I met people, they really like me for me and maybe want to get to another step. Doctor: Step and they don’t feel comfortable. Patient: You know. Doctor: Do they know about your situation? Have you talked about that?

Patient: Yeah. Could we do it Thursday afternoon? Doctor: Sure, yeah. Family Member: It’s just an echo… Patient: How long does it take – to do that ? Doctor: It’s about, not a very long time, but it would mean that I would just need to, we would need to coordinate the echo appointment and all that- that’s why I’m just asking you for Patient: Thursday afternoon. Doctor: -a few days. that work out well for you Because… Patient: Thursday afternoon. We’re going to Canada on Saturday morning. Doctor: Okay and then next week. Patient: Closer than Vancouver. Doctor: Fair enough. Next week anytime? Family Member: For the same thing?

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.5-9 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::5-9 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.disagree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::disagree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.neutral: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::neutral

People of my ethnic group are treated th.neutral: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::neutral

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Sure. Doctor: And that doesn’t commit us to absolutely do this study or… Patient: Yeah. Right. Family Member: It gets the ball rolling. Doctor: Correct. Exactly. And finding out that information is useful anyway even down the road. Even if you don’t do this particular study. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. More information is always better. Doctor: Yeah, yeah. Family Member: We will be…I mean it’s hard to tell at this point, but would we be coming back basically the same day? Or no? Doctor: Uh when for uh typically. Family Member: Tuesdays work really well for me because… Doctor: We’ll try and keep it. Family Member: …it’s dead quiet on Tuesday’s you know so that works out real well. But -

Patient: No, I’ve just seen my regular doctor. Family Member: He just told me. He was hiding it from me. Doctor: Ah. Well, you know, getting that sort of worked out because we could always do that in the between. Just because this is a six month go Patient: Right. Okay. Okay. Doctor: we can always pause because hernia surgery is outpatient nowadays too so you just need healing time. Patient: Right. Doctor: And this stuff only goes to bone and your hernia surgery is not bone so it’s all workable. Patient: Okay they may say it’s not necessary either. Doctor: Yeah, correct, correct, but go ahead and have your primary refer you to a hernia surgeon. Okay? Patient: Okay, yep. Doctor: Might as well get that all taken care of. Patient: Okay, alright. Well, this sounds good to me.

Patient: I haven’t talked to him. Doctor: No but when they did the testing? Patient: Oh he said it’s worse. Doctor: It’s worse? Patient: A little worse, yeah. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. The um… Doctor: So the strength was worse? Patient: Right. Doctor: That was worse. That would be the reason then to do… Patient: Right, right. Doctor: …you know to lean towards surgery. Because if it’s going to take the pressure off the nerve…

Family Member: But I was on a higher dose. You’re saying, uh, a lower dose. Doctor: Yeah. What dose were you on? Family Member: Uh, well, when I, I was diagnosed with Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: They had put me on like, it was like eighty milligrams, but then they brought me down because my face was all ballooned out. Doctor: And so this is five a day, five milligrams. Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but.

Patient: Yesterday for some reason all in my back was pain from my shoulder blades, to my shoulders all through my back. And I took a uh Nap-nabarone. Doctor: N-naprosyn. Patient: Yeah I took and sleep Doctor: Okay. And did you take one today as well? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. So it didn’t come back today? Patient: No. Doctor: Um hum. Have you been losing or gaining any weight? Patient: Uh, I guess I been Doctor: And do you think that’s because your appetite has dropped or you’re losing even if you’re eating the same amount. Patient: Somewhat the same amount. Doctor: Okay. And can you remind me who lives with you at home? Are you on your own or do you have other family members with you?

Family Member: Even though when they get him they go to the Docetaxal? Doctor: Now, Oh, well, from a chemo standpoint we might have to negotiate that. For sure if you get on the high-dose vitamin C one that is more labor intensive because the chemo is once every three months, not three months, once every three weeks. He got hopeful there for a minute. No, sorry, once every three weeks but the vitamin C is twice a week because it’s at such a high dose. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Well, think about normal stuff you would pop every day you’d almost have to take it multiple times a day to get that dose. This would be the super high one so you’re here like twice a week for like weeks and months. I mean we hope it’s that long because that means it’s working, but yeah, that’s a bit of a slightly draining on that one Patient: Yeah. Doctor: but I have a lot of people who just want their hands on high-dose vitamin C because this is you know, formulated differently than just sort of generic stuff. This is really done with the right, you know, it’s made by a company that’s sort of a spinoff of Hopkins so it’s a very well-regulated product. Um, but, can I tell you that if you’re on placebo you still have to be here? Yeah, because I don’t know who’s getting what. So, the three of us would be fast friends for weeks. Every day it’d be like hello, hello. Just take your name and tape it on an infusion area and you’ll see M____ and S____ all the time. So, that’s one but we’ll work on that. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Yeah, we might need, if it’s something that frequent, we might need a port. Yeah, that’s a lot of beating up on you. You know, once every three weeks Patient: Right, Right. Doctor: you can get away with that and it’s like an hour but if you’re here twice a week it’s pretty painful. Patient: That’s possible that I don’t have to do that, right? Doctor: Well, you could always say no. You could say listen, I just want the chemo and I don’t want the vitamin C trial, just you know forget it and we would just do straight chemo. Patient: Okay.

Family Member: No. Doctor: No. No. That’s the Zytiga drug. We’re going to table that for now. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Yeah. One is a random study, study, so it’s like a, there’s a possibility you just get the standard, the drug. The other I think- Family Member: You get both? Doctor: You get both. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: I, I don’t know enough about either drug in terms of the side effect profile. I, I know the one where you get one or the other has been pretty well tolerated. Uh, and the other drug is, uh, I haven’t put anybody on the trial yet, so I don’t have the experience, but, uh, I know from our meetings, I haven’t heard any signal that says this is horribly toxic. So, uh, so I, I think side effect wise, I don’t think that we’re going to have that much problem. It’s really just a matter of can we-? Family Member: So they saw a lot of more spots on his bone from the last, uh-? Doctor: Yeah. Let me, uh, pull that up. So- (pause14sec) Patient: Um hum. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, right. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: It’s too bad they haven’t came up with something more with the bones whereas they can, you know?

Patient: No. Uh uh. Oh, you all gon’ call me today or tomorrow about the blood work, right? Doctor: As soon as I have your PSA test which either be uh late this afternoon or early tomorrow morning, I’m going to call you at the (doc recites patient’s telephone number) Patient: Right. Doctor: Phone number. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Is is that the best for you? Patient: Yes. Mhm. Doctor: Okay. Alright, anything else you need from me today? Patient: No sir. Doctor: Okay, let’s get you home. How did you get here today? Did you- Patient: By cab. Doctor: By cab? Patient: I I think sh-she wants to um call for me.

Patient: Well then – Doctor: And then we think about what’s necessary. Patient: That’s what the, the doctor at P_ said. Doctor: I know! Patient: He say, he say – Doctor: I talked to that doctor, remember? Patient: Yeah! You told me he talked to you. Doctor: I know. Patient: You say. Doctor: So, I said, I know you. That if we did that and everything else, you would just sort of give up. You’d be like, “I’m done. I can just barely -- my quality of life is here.” But I have to tell you, if you really needed it. One, I think your quality of life would actually be much better because you’d be so symptomatic from that problem, you couldn’t ride your bike. You couldn’t go around the block. You couldn’t do anything! You’d just be soiling yourself constantly! So, if that came to be the issue, you would want it done just to improve your quality of life. Patient: Okay. Listen. Doctor: But I also know that that’s not something you would do proactively because the thought of having a bag scares the heck out of you. I know that. I got it. And now I just threw in two possible bags that’s even more frightening. So, I need you to focus on what we have to do next. We gotta get some systemic stuff swirling through your bloodstream –
